did.abstract: The personal papers of artist, designer, and visual theorist György Kepes.
did.langmaterial: While most of the collection is in English, there is also a significant amount of Hungarian text, as well as printed material in German, Italian, Japanese, and other languages.
did.physloc: Special Collections and University Archives materials are stored offsite and must be paged 36 hours in advance.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Artist, designer, and visual theorist György Kepes was born in 1906 in Selyp, Hungary. Originally associated with Germany’s Bauhaus as a colleague of László Moholy-Nagy, he emigrated to the United States in 1937 to teach Light and Color at Moholy's New Bauhaus (soon to be called the Institute of Design) in Chicago. In 1944, he produced Language of Vision, a landmark book about design theory, followed by the publication of six Kepes-edited anthologies in a series called Vision + Value as well as several other books. In addition to being a prolific painter and photographer, Kepes relentlessly explored the various crossed paths between art and the sciences. In 1956, The New Landscape in Art and Science, an exhibition (and later book) focused on these interests, gathering scientific imagery including x-ray, infra-red, microscope and telescope photographs. Several original panels from this exhibition are present in the collection. Kepes began teaching at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1947, first as an associate professor of visual design and becoming a full professor in 1949. As the first artist-in-residence, he encouraged collaboration between artists, designers, architects, and engineers by organizing seminars, workshops and exhibitions. In 1967 Kepes founded MIT's Center for Advanced Visual Studies (CAVS) and was its director until 1972, retiring two years later. Kepes died in 2001 at the age of 95.

accessrestrict.head: Access to Collection
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use. Audio-visual materials are not available in original format, and must be reformatted to a digital use copy. Selected video has been transferred and is available digitally.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: While Special Collections is the owner of the physical and digital items, permission to examine collection materials is not an authorization to publish. These materials are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study. Any transmission or reproduction beyond that allowed by fair use requires permission from the owners of rights, heir(s) or assigns

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was purchased by Stanford University, Special Collections in 2010. Accessions 2010-186, 2011-058, and 2012-063.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Gyorgy Kepes papers (M1796). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Archives of American Art holds the Gyorgy Kepes papers, 1825-1989: http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/gyorgy-kepes-papers-725.

The Art Institute of Chicago holds the papers of Kepes' publisher Paul Theobold: Theobald, Paul, and Company Records, 1935-1988. http://digital-libraries.saic.edu/cdm/ref/collection/findingaids/id/14478

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Gyorgy Kepes collection contains manuscripts, typescripts, notes, research files, correspondence, photographs, slides & exhibition panels, artwork, catalogues, publications, media, and other material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly scientific images and paintings. Some or all are produced by Kepes or used in projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 5 photographs of typography and writing systems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box of 130 negatives for reproduction in various Kepes publications but also other miscellaneous negatives. Note: images are not necessarily from Kepes's "Language of Vision" despite typed label on original Kodak photo box. Includes for example a negative of a New York Times Book Review article on Kepes's Vision + Value Series by Roger Jellinek. Some negatives include handwritten captions or citations on note, envelope, or negative; most reproduce images from other publications and include original text or caption copy in negative. Masking applied to some negatives in preparation for printing. Images include Balla painting, Futurist topography, Georges Seurat painting, diagrams from art and design textbooks, movement diagrams, Soviet posters, installation shot of design exhibition, and many others. Includes duplicates.

Ginsburg of the USAF, published in NAECON and dated 1973, along with 6 photographs of images included in report. Also includes photographs of works from the MIT Visual Design Course, tearsheet of El Lissitizy reproductions, 3 postcards from the British Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Includes photographs of a Chinese ceremonial blade, typewriters, an aerial view of Earth, a Native American bowl with insect design. Also includes unsigned photograph possibly by Kepes titled "Light Tapestry" and dated 1939-1940 with attached handwritten note, and a second photograph signed by Kepes titled "Light Study of Rhytm [sic]" and dated 1949, with similar untitled and unsigned photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes undated and untitled typescript and many pages of notes in pencil and in original order; many pages labeled with "intrinsic symbol." Themes include urbanism, cities, and the definition of symbol.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescripts titled "Light and Color" and dated 11/5/64 and 11/17/64, handwritten notes on "modulation" and "light modulation," "figure - ground," "randomness," "visual fundamentals," "light," "education of vision," "light source," "light window," "lighting design," "aesthetic factors," "The new landscape," "light duration," "light + space," "light information," and various other topics related to light. Includes drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed page dated 3/29/67 on "color," handwritten notes on "light space," "light color," "light motion," "light modulation," "modelling," "Education of vision -- light environment," "sender, transmitter, receiver," "light modulation scale," "light terminology," "light science," "light general," "color of light," and various other topics related to light. Includes drawings. Includes typed Charles Bunn quotation on diamonds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript titled "Light and Color" dated 12/15/64, handwritten notes on "city," "Eduction of vision standardization conventionalization of forms," "most important epistemological problems," "light + shadow," "challenge for change," "mobile light sources," "scheme," "projected light," "light space," "what color can do," and various other notes relating to light. New York Times newspaper clippings titled "Glare Is Eliminated by New Plastic Lens" and "Scientists Weigh Astronaut Mystery," and article titled "The Leonid meteors" from The Listener. Typed page on student work, M.I.T Visual Design Course. Four untitled typescripts and two miscellaneous typed pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partial typescript on "light messages. Handwritten notes on "stage lighting," "light optical echo," "information figure-ground," "light motion change," "geometry-fluidity," "architectural use," "figure ground role of contrast," "light + form," "surface modulation," "light information, communication," "light reflection (scale)," "figure-ground formation/information," "Rules of the Game," and other notes on light. Pamphlet on color charts, two pages of typed grant proposal or application. 1 miscellaneous typed sheet. Typed manuscript titled "LIGHT" dated 2/16/67.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes on "color," "history of color use," "education of vision - unity of opposites," "light illlumination direction," "light technology," "light technology stage," "New light technology," "light sources," and various other notes relating to light. Typed agenda for "Vision, Brightness, and Design" seminar, 9/23-24/1953. Miscellaneous typed pages. Single page from Kepes's "The Visual Arts and the Sciences" article printed in Daedalus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript on "Light and Color Tools (2)" dated 11/3/64, Handwritten notes on "light-mythology," "light modulation," "light color," "light science," 'light + shadow." Includes miscellaneous typed sheets. Letter from Mrs. Karl T. Compton and Boston Council for International Visitors, letter to Julie Kepes re: print exhibition at Wake Forest College, typed assignment for "ADVANCED VISUAL DESIGN" by J.J. Schiffer, typescript on stained glass by Robert P. Breading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box of 64 negatives presumably for reproduction in "Language of Vision" and possibly later Kepes publications. Some include handwritten captions or citations. Most reproduce images from prior publications and include original text or caption copy. Masking was applied to some negatives in preparation for reproduction. Images include Vincent Van Gogh drawing, promotional image of Charlie Chaplin in City Lights, illustration of a Japanese garden, Picasso drawing, Poussin's "Rape of the Sabine Women," Chinese seals, images of animal structures, topography, and many others. Includes slides of Kepes's own drawings in "Language of Vision."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1965-1966, Kepes edited a set of six anthologies, published as the Vision + Value Series by George Braziller. Each volume contained essays by artists, designers, architects and scientists, as well as many photographs and illustrations. The volumes were as follows: The Education of Vision; Structure in Art and Science; The Nature and Art of Motion; Module, Symmetry, Proportion, Rhythm; Sign, Image, Symbol; and The Man-Made Object.

did.unittitle: Vision and Value series correspondence with George Braziler re: Italian edition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note: 63 photographs in original order. Photographs of works by Maxime Descombin, Wen-Ying Tsai, Max Bill, Simon Nicholson, Geny Dignac, Masayuki Nagare, Dan Flavin, and others. Roger J. Chen scientific photograpy of ice crystal formation. Photographs of power plants, refineries, and heavy industry from the Tennessee Valley Authority and Standard Oil Company. Photographs by William Garnet, Gyorgy Kepes, Martin S. Dworkin, Donald Olson, and others. Reproductions of photocollages by Friedrich St. Florian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note: 115 photographs in original order. photographs of works by David Temiers, Stan Vanderbeek, and Jan Ossenbeck. Photographic documentation of events by Theo Botschuijver and Jeffrey Shaw, from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, and various images of dances, rituals, ceremonies, student protests, and parades. Includes images of the Wailing Wall, the Woodstock festival, Les Halles market in Paris, and many others. Also contains photographs by G. Duby, Dan Brody for the Harvard Crimson, Peter Moore, and others. Includes letter from Theo Botschuijver and Jeffrey Shaw re: photographs. Includes three pages of notes from G. Kepes re: captions for various Vision and Value publications. Postcard from the British Museum.

Typescript titled "THE PERCEPTUAL FORM OF THE CITY GENERAL REPORT AND PLAN FOR FUTURE STUDIES -- May 17, 1955." Typescript titled "A FRAMEWORK FOR THE FORM OF CITY STUDY AND SOME TOPICS FOR STUDY." Typescript titled "NOTES ON DISCUSSION BETWEEN L.A. AND J.R.M AND G.K., K.L. AND J.R.MM. ON OR ABOUT MARCH 20, 1958." Typed proposal dated March 4, 1954 and titled "Proposed Study: THE PERCEPTUAL FORM OF THE CITY." Memo from Dave Crane to G. Kepes and associated typed notes for Crane lecture given at Harvard Graduate School of Design 1/6/56. Typed bibliography titled "Recomended References on the Form of the City."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters may have been removed from other files and assembled here; however, not all of the correspondence may be considered especially noteworthy. Included here are letters from the following: Josef Albers 4/15/58 ; Buckminster Fuller 1/21/81 (photocopy) ; Walter Gropius 3/16/61 ; Philip Johnson 11/1/47 ; Lazlo Maholy-Nagy 9/20/45 (encouraging Kepes to contribute photos to his forthcoming "Vision in Motion" book) ; I.A. Richards 5/6/70 ; Erik Erikson, undated ; Josep Luis Sert 7/10/69 ; Aaron Siskind 5/3/55 ; Edwards Steichen 4/6/61 ; Kenzo Tange 12/10/64 ; Robert Jay Wolff 8/7/74 (missing a page). There are also letters from San Francisco gallery owner Stephen Wirtz, Robert Brown of the Archives of American Art, and researcher Reinhold Martin to Kepes' daughter in 2003. Two outgoing drafts by Kepes are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains exhibition catalogs, articles, essays, pamphlets, and transcripts, as well as some photographs and correspondence. Includes material from MIT CAVS Fellows Michio Ihara, Piotr Kowalski, Rockne Krebs, Antonio Muntadas, Alejandro Otero, Otto Piene, Athena Tacha, Vassilakis Takis, and Wen-Ying Tsai. Other significant items include exhibition notices from the Lazlo Maholy-Nagy memorial exhibition at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1947, Piet Mondrian at Sidney Janis in 1951, and Jackson Pollock at Betty Parsons also in 1951. Some items are inscribed to Kepes.
